In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  implementation  of  the  Pacific 
Region  Infrastructure  Facility  (PRIF)  through  development  and  operation  of  the  PRIF 
Coordination  Office  for  3  years.  The  PRIF  is  a  multipartner  investment  coordination  and 
technical facility, which supports infrastructure development and maintenance in the Pacific. The 
TA design is based on extensive consultation with PRIF partners.1 The project design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Extensive analysis of development issues confronting Pacific  island countries3 have 
identified the following key drivers of change: (i) an improved private sector environment, (ii) 
improved public sector management, (iii) capacity development, (iv) climate change adaptation 
and mitigation, (v) development partnerships, and (vi) gender mainstreaming.4 In particular, 
institutional weakness and limited capacity were identified as major constraints on infrastructure 
development and maintenance in the Pacific. The Pacific Approach (footnote 4) notes that the 
region suffers from infrastructure projects planned and financed without adequate institutional 
and human capacity development efforts which, when combined with a weak policy environment, 
results in unsustainable infrastructure development. The analysis concludes that TA support for 
capacity  development  and  policy  and  institutional  reforms  has  resulted  in  demonstrated 
improvements  in  infrastructure  delivery,  and  calls  for  a  long-term  approach  to  capacity 
development by development partners.  
 
3.  Core issues for delivery of infrastructure services in the Pacific include (i) loss of synergy 
through  operating  competitively  rather  than  collaboratively;  (ii)  institutional  structures 
inappropriate to sustaining quality service delivery; (iii) lack of regulatory capacity to protect the 
public  interest  and  foster  greater  private  sector  participation;  (iv)  lack  of  appropriate  and 
affordable training; and (v) limited expertise at critical stages of sector reform such as legislative 
drafting, policy formulation, financial and tariff modeling, and engineering inputs.5 These factors 
contribute  to  a  lack  of  maintenance,  inappropriate  technology,  and  frequently  unaffordable 
solutions to infrastructure needs. Development partners have often been part of the problem by 
imposing external priorities, overburdening fragile administrative and management systems, and 
operating competitively in their own interests rather than collaboratively in the partner country’s 
interest. 
 
4.  To address these issues, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has formed a partnership 
with the Australian Agency for International Development, New Zealand Ministry of Foreign 
Affairs and Trade, the World Bank Group (including the International Finance Corporation), 
European Commission, and European Investment Bank to create the PRIF. The purpose of the 
facility  is  to  improve  development  effectiveness  and  the  sustainability  of  infrastructure 
investments by strengthening coordination among development partners; improving policies and 
                                                
1  PRIF partners are Asian Development Bank, Australian Agency for International Development, New Zealand 
Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade, World Bank Group (including the International Finance Corporation), 
European Commission, and European Investment Bank. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) website on 24 
January 2013.  
3  PRIF covers 12 Pacific island countries: Cook Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, 
Nauru, Niue, Palau, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, and Vanuatu.   
4  ADB. 2009. Pacific Approach 2010–2014. Manila.  
5  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Improving Delivery of Infrastructure Services. Manila (TA 6257-REG).

regulations; increasing infrastructure cofinancing; and improving the capacity of Pacific island 
countries to prioritize, plan, develop, and maintain infrastructure investments.6 
 
5.  The PRIF initiative was officially launched in August 2008 at the Pacific Islands Forum. 
The  facility  covers  12  Pacific  island  countries7 and  supports  five  economic  infrastructure 
subsectors  (energy;  telecommunications;  road,  aviation,  and  maritime  transport;  waste 
management; and water and sanitation). The work of the PRIF has been managed by (i) a 
development partner coordination function supervised by the PRIF Secretariat located within the 
World Bank Sydney office (two full-time consultants), and (ii) a technical assistance support 
facility (Pacific Infrastructure Advisory Center [PIAC]8) located in the ADB Pacific Liaison and 
Coordination Office (PLCO) in Sydney (four full-time consultants). The initial phase of both 
these functions commenced in August 2009 and is scheduled to end in April 2013. The PRIF’s 
work plan is guided by the interdevelopment-partner PRIF Management Committee (PMC)9 and 
senior management team consisting of representatives from each PRIF partner.  
 
6.  The PRIF initiative is a multipartner investment coordination and TA mechanism and is a 
significant joint commitment to improving infrastructure services in the region in accordance with 
the  Paris  Declaration  on  Aid  Effectiveness  and  the  Cairns  Compact  on  Strengthening 
Development Coordination. Since its launch, the PRIF has provided a successful mechanism for 
coordinating  PRIF  partner  infrastructure  investment  and  providing  technical  assistance  to 
participating Pacific island countries. The PRIF provides a platform and dedicated resources to 
enable development partners to better coordinate and harmonize their support, and, in doing so, 
better address the economic infrastructure needs of Pacific island countries. This proposed TA 
will consolidate the gains to date and provide ongoing resources to scale up the initiative. 
 
7.  Two independent reviews have provided guidance to the PMC and senior management 
team on development of the PRIF.10 The reviews acknowledge the benefits provided through 
the PRIF initiative of improved development partner coordination and TA.11 The Management 
and Governance Options Analysis (footnote 10) recommends that the current functions of the 
PIAC and the PRIF Secretariat should be continued, but should be brought together under a 
single PRIF coordination office. The analysis also indicated broad appreciation by Pacific island 
countries for the activities of PIAC and the PRIF Secretariat and strong desire to continue the 
support provided.12 In response to the independent reviews, and as requested by the PRIF 
partners, ADB proposes to host the combined PRIF coordination office at the PLCO. This will 
continue to locate the PRIF initiative close to PRIF development partners. Locating the PRIF

increasing project co-financing, managing PRIF coordination meetings and disseminating data between partners of 
infrastructure pipelines. PIAC has provided a range of technical assistance including preparation of national 
infrastructure investment plans for 6 Pacific island countries, Pacific utility benchmarking studies for power and 
water sector, institutional support for over 10 power and power utilities, 3 scoping studies for maritime port 
infrastructure, 5 analytical studies and development of Pacific infrastructure performance indicators.     
12 PIAC is currently implementing approximately 25 technical assistance projects. However, PIAC receives 30-40 
requests for annum for technical assistance, demonstrating a high demand for assistance from the Pacific island 
countries.

3 
coordination office in PLCO will also improve coordination with the Private Sector Development 
Initiative, which is also located at the PLCO. The proposed TA will support both the PRIF 
partner coordination function (currently implemented through the PRIF Secretariat) and the TA 
function (currently implemented through the PIAC). The independent reviews also provided 
recommendations to improve PRIF design, which have been incorporated into the design of the 
consolidated  PRIF  coordination  office,  including  (i)  establishing  lead  sector  coordinators, 
nominated by the PRIF partners, (ii) enhancing research agenda of infrastructure development 
in  the  Pacific,  (iii)  improving  communication  with  Pacific  island  countries  through  a  PRIF 
communications strategy, and (iv) enhancing PRIF partner harmonization.   
 
8.  The proposed TA is included in the Pacific regional operations business plan, 2013–
2015  as  a  2013  nonlending  activity.13 The  proposed  TA  supports the plan’s  emphasis  on 
strengthening  core  government  functions,  including  policy  formulation  and  public  sector 
management. The design of the proposed PRIF coordination office is based on the design of 
the  existing  PRIF  Secretariat  and  PIAC,  however  the  design  also  incorporates  the 
recommendations  of  independent  evaluations  (footnote  10)  and  direction  from  the  senior 
management team. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be improved quality of infrastructure investments in the Pacific island 
countries.  The  outcome  will  be  the  governments  of  the  Pacific  island  countries  receive 
comprehensive and coordinated support and TA on infrastructure investments. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The proposed TA will support implementation of the PRIF through development and 
operation of the PRIF coordination office. The outputs of the project are as follows:  
 
(i)  Improved  coordination  of  Pacific  Region  Infrastructure  Facility  partner 
infrastructure investments in the Pacific. PRIF partner infrastructure investments 
will be coordinated through the PRIF coordination office. The PRIF coordination 
office will include six core consultants who will be responsible for facilitating PRIF 
partner  coordination  and  providing  short-term  TA  support  to  the  Pacific  island 
countries and PRIF partners. The core team will be supported by individual short-
term consultants who will undertake targeted TA activities. The PRIF coordination 
office  will  provide  support  to  five  economic  infrastructure  subsectors  (energy; 
telecommunications; road,  aviation,  and maritime transport;  waste management; 
and  water  and  sanitation).  The  PRIF  coordination  office  operations  will  be 
undertaken in accordance with the PRIF operations manual, and activities will be 
implemented as detailed in the annual PRIF work plan. Monitoring of results will be 
through  the  PRIF  results  framework,  which  will  include  the  project  design  and 
monitoring framework. The PRIF coordination office will coordinate infrastructure 
delivery by PRIF partners by  
(a)  coordinating PMC and senior management team meetings,  
(b)  implementing an approved program of research and analysis of infrastructure 
issues in the Pacific,  
                                                
13   ADB. 2012. Pacific: Regional Operations and Business Plan, 2013–2015. Manila.

4   
(c)  assisting lead sector coordinators in sector coordination activities,  
(d)  maintaining the PRIF website containing publicly available information on 
PRIF partner activities,  
(e)  facilitating interpartner technical review of infrastructure investment design 
documents,  
(f)  implementing a PRIF communications strategy,  
(g)  maintaining a PRIF partner activity database,  
(h)  facilitating increased cofinancing activities, and  
(i)  facilitating delivery of a PRIF harmonization agenda.   
 
(ii)  Governments of the Pacific island countries and Pacific Region Infrastructure 
Facility  partners  receive  technical  advice  on  infrastructure  development. 
Technical  advice  will  be  provided  by  the  PRIF  coordination  office,  including 
infrastructure development plans (either national infrastructure plans or sector plans) 
and provide infrastructure policy, regulatory, and project implementation advice. The 
PRIF coordination office will also provide TA to the Pacific island countries as short-
term  inputs  (less  than  6  months  continuous)  of  technical  expertise  to  support 
implementation  and  evaluation  of  infrastructure  investments  across  the  target 
infrastructure  sectors,  including  both  public  and  private  sectors.  The  PRIF 
coordination office will manage the quality assurance of TA support, as well as TA 
for  knowledge  products  for  infrastructure  in  the  Pacific  in  accordance  with  an 
approved research program. 
 
11.  Major assumptions are that the Pacific island countries will continue to improve the 
quality  of their  public  expenditure, maintain  or  increase  budget allocation for  infrastructure 
maintenance,  utilize  infrastructure  planning  documents,  and  continue  to  demand  external 
advisory services. It is also assumed that PRIF partners will remain committed to increased 
coordination and harmonization. Major risks are (i) limited capacity of government agencies in 
the Pacific island countries to implement infrastructure plans, (ii) poor availability of data that 
could reduce the quality of analyses, and (iii) that some PRIF partner business processes are 
difficult to harmonize. The major risks will be managed by (i) ensuring infrastructure plans are 
designed considering capacity of the Pacific island country governments, and by undertaking 
capacity development activities; (ii) supporting data collection activities by the PRIF coordination 
office; and (iii) engaging in dialogue with PRIF partners regarding system harmonizing.      
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $11.8 million, of which $0.5 million (4.2%) will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V), and $11.3 million will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Australia ($8.9 million equivalent, 75.5%) 
and the Government of New Zealand ($2.4 million equivalent, 20.3%). ADB will administer the 
grants. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA. The TA will require a total of 318 person-
months of international consultants and 168 person-months of national consultants to be hired 
through  individual  consultant  selection.14 Six  full-time  consultants  (three  international  [108 
                                                
14 The consultants will be recruited on an individual basis because (i) the three international specialists will fill 
complex and sensitive roles that require direct control over selection, (ii) there are only three international staff to

5 
person-months] and three national [108 person-months]) will be recruited as the core team for 
the PRIF coordination office for an initial 3-year period.15 The TA will be implemented between 
April  2013  and  April  2016.  The  core  team  will  be  supported  by  specialized  short-term 
consultants  (international  210  person-months  and  national  60  person-months)  who  will  be 
recruited through a combination of individual consultant selection and indefinite delivery contract. 
The specialized short-term consultants will also be required for specific on-demand assignments 
that result from government or PRIF partner demand for support with analysis, advice, project 
preparation, implementation, and review in the focal sectors. Terms of reference for short-term 
assignments will be prepared by the PRIF coordination office core team and submitted for 
clearance by the PMC. Consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment and materials 
financed under the technical assistance will be procured by the PRIF coordination office core 
team in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
At completion of the project, equipment and materials will either be transferred to subsequent 
phases of the PRIF or provided to participating Pacific island countries, as determined by the 
PMC. Training and workshops will be implemented through the consultants’ contracts. The 
proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
14.  Governments  of  the  Pacific  island  countries  will  provide  counterpart  support  and 
services including counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative support costs, and 
logistics costs. The PMC will approve the PRIF coordination office annual work plan and any 
proposed  variations  to  the  work  plan.  The  PRIF  coordination  office  will  prepare  quarterly 
progress reports, which will outline activities undertaken and progress towards performance 
indicators. The PMC will approve the quarterly progress reports. Sector work undertaken by the 
PRIF coordination office will be guided by the  lead sector coordinators (representatives from 
the PRIF partners) who will coordinate technical input from sector specialists within the PRIF 
partners. The outputs will be monitored through a PRIF results framework and disseminated 
through quarterly  newsletters  and  annual  reports.  The  PRIF  coordination  office  includes  a 
results and research manager who will develop a communications strategy to disseminate 
information on PRIF coordination office activities. An independent review of PRIF coordination 
office activities will be undertaken after the end of the second year of operation. No activities will 
be undertaken in participating countries until no-objection letters have been obtained.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION  
 
15.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering a portion of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $11.3 million for Establishment of the 
Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility Coordination Office, to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Australia (A$8.5 million) and the Government of New Zealand (NZ$3.0 million). 
If the Board approves ADB administering the technical assistance, the President, acting under 
the authority delegated by the Board, approves ADB providing the balance of the technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $0.5 million on a grant basis, for Establishment of 
the Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility Coordination Office.
